TopicTitle: The UM-1 Ultra Manueverable Stunt Plane

Articles.Content:
I was experimenting with ultra maneuverable designs and the results were fairly good, and the UM-1 was born. This has almost VTOL like properties with the way it maneuvers and can pull a 180 degree turn at any speed extremely quick using super maneuverability, the plane doesn't have that much lift and I think a majority of it's maneuverability relies on it's Panther engines. It has a max speed of around 1000 m/s. What I show below is a few stunts I did with it, surprisingly easily. It also has a very low stall speed. Without further adieu, here's the video!

Aircraft Download: https://www.dropbox.com/s/gw9zohd8ngyq8ib/UM.craft?dl=0

Subscribe if you wanna!

 

 

Once again, feedback is appreciated like, subscribe and share if you want to!

Here's my newest replica video of a F/A-18!

 

F/A-18 Download: https://www.dropbox.com/s/820duijrxokrvfh/F-18A.craft?dl=0

 

Edited February 10, 2016 by AquaAlmond Productions

Incredible!
Is this beauty stock? How many parts? WANT THE CRAFT!

13 minutes ago, Sobas said:

Incredible!
Is this beauty stock? How many parts? WANT THE CRAFT!

Yes, it's all stock! 50 parts and download coming soon!
 

It also flies pretty easy with SAS off and is surprisingly quick when it's panther engines are in wet mode. It reaches speeds of around 1000 m/s and you can do very sharp turns at high speeds.

"Most maneuverable plane ever made"

I, for one, doubt that. It's okay to use hyperbole, but add a bit of a disclaimer if you do.

And I've made one in stock aero that literally turns on a dime. It does use a bit of RCS engine thrust, but it flips almost instantly. And by literally, I mean it.

5 minutes ago, The Optimist said:

"Most maneuverable plane ever made"

I, for one, doubt that. It's okay to use hyperbole, but add a bit of a disclaimer if you do.

Title fixed. Better now?

This actually makes me wonder where we should draw the line between maneuverability and aerodynamic instability.

Oh well, the F-16 was purposely made aerodynamically unstable in order to achieve better maneuverability, so I guess it's alright.

2 minutes ago, pTrevTrevs said:

This actually makes me wonder where we should draw the line between maneuverability and aerodynamic instability.

Oh well, the F-16 was purposely made aerodynamically unstable in order to achieve better maneuverability, so I guess it's alright.

I'd still call it maneuverable over instable. It can pull incredibly sharp turns. However yes it is a bit unstable but that was purposely done so it can make those turns.

At higher speeds, my craft turn on a dime as well.

Though they do have a tendency to snap in two when I try to do so. And the thing is that real life aircraft turn with their momentum, while ours just pivot.

I had the same problem, that's why there is something like 12 struts under the hull of the aircraft so it doesn't tear itself apart
It being very light, (About 6 tons maybe less) also helps a lot.

I made a topic in the challenges and idea's topic. The challenge is to try to land the plane on the roof of the VAB without breaking anything, and then put your video of doing it in the comments.

Noticed it. Though I think it would be more fun to include the engineering into the challenge. As in landing a 'conventional' plane there, that only has backwards facing engines.

I'd also add to use destructible facilities for extra fun, but there's no way to check if it's actually the case on a submission.

Thanks man. Ill definitely look at that.

Now static maneuverability is a bit different from maneuverability at speed. Your jet has such a small lift coeficcient that at speed it will maneuver off vector well, but attempting to maneuver at low speed will just flip you. With such a low surface area of lift, you won't bite the air.

1 hour ago, SpaceToad said:

I will consider that in my next build
